nodes.description: Chemicals used as abrasives in industrial or domestic applications.
Chemical precursors used in the synthesis of acaricides.
Pesticides that kill members of the arachnid subclass Acari, including spiders, ticks and mites.
Substances that can increase the speed of a chemical process.
Chemicals that are either adhesive, or are additives in adhesive mixtures.
A sbustance that is used to increase the efficacy of another drug.
A substance that stimulates a response from adrenergic receptors, mimicking the effects of epinephrine.
A suspension of fine particulates in air.
Aqueous film forming foams. Firefighting foams made from surfactants and PFAS.
Poisonous chemicals produced by certain molds, notably by Aspergillus.
An organic compound with an aldehyde functional group.
Pesticides that kill and prevent the growth of algae.
Metals in group 1 of the periodic table.
Basic organic compounds that contain at least one nitrogen atom.
Chemicals that act as alkyl group donors.
Man-made compounds where a carbon atom of one or more organic moleculse is bound to lead.
Substances that are used as ingredients in alloys.
Organic compounds that contain both amino and carboxylic acid functional groups.
Any organic molecule that contains amino sugar substructures, generally used as antibiotics.
Minerals of igneous or metamorphic origin that form prism or needle-like crystals.
Steroid hormones that bind to androgen receptors in vertebrates, which are used for hormonal replacement therapy and for stimulating the growth of muscles and bones.
A drug that is used to relieve pain.
Steroid hormones that bind to androgen receptors in vertebrates, which regulates the development and maintenance of male characteristics.
A drug that is used to induce anesthesia.
An intermediate or end product of animal (including human) metabolism.
Inorganic entities with a net negative charge.
A group of Antiparasitics that target parasitic worms (helminths).
Chemicals that are used in products for the treatment of acne.
Chemicals that hinder the adhesive properties of adhesive agents.
Antrimicrobial substances that are used as medications for fighting bacterial infections.
Substances used as additives in materials to prevent the formation of lumps.
Substances that block the action of acetylcholine.
Substances used as medications for treating epileptic seizures.
Chemicals that are used as pharmaceuticals to alleviate depression.
Substances used to combat diabetes.
Substances used to reduce nausea and prevent vomiting.
Chemicals that lower the freezing point of a water-based mixture.
Substances used to treat and or prevent glaucoma related issues.
Substances that block histamine to combat allergic reactions.
Substances used to combat hypertension.
Chemicals that are used to kill microorganisms.
Substances used as medications for treating and preventing mycosis.
Substances used as medications for treating cancer.
Substances that are used as additives to inhibit oxidation.
Substances that are used as medications for treating and preventing parasites.
Chemicals that are used as pharmaceuticals to treat psychotic disorders.
Substances that are used as medications for reducing fevers.
Antimicrobial substances that are applied to living tissue to reduce the possibility of infection.
Chemicals that are used to remove stains from clothing.
Chemicals used on materials to reduce the buildup of static electricity.
Substances used as medications for suppressing coughs.
Substances that are used as medications for treating viral infections.
A substance that is used to suppress a persons appetite.
A chemical that shrinks body tissue.
Chemicals that are used as additives in automotive fluids. For example, motor oil and transmission fluids.
Prokaryotic microorganisms, some of which can cause disease.
A class of of drugs commonly used as Anesthetics and anticonvulsants that are derived from Barbituric acid.
Substances used as medications that relax airway muscles resulting in easier breathing by interacting with beta receptors.
Substances that holds materials together to form a cohesive whole.
Substances that is used to destroy, deter, render harmless, or exert a controlling effect on any harmful organism.
Chemicals that are used as measurable indicators of some biological state or condition.
Chemicals used to remove color from fabric or fiber.
Chemical compounds that causes severe skin, eye and mucosal pain and irritation. Generally in reference to a chemical warfare agent.
Chemical compounds that are absorbed readiliy into blood and act as lethal poisons. Generally in reference to a chemical warfare agent.
Substances that are used to produce a cellular structure in materials that undergo hardening or a phase transition.
Chemicals that are primarily found within plant sources. For example, curcumin is produced by plants of the Curcuma longa species.
Substances used as medications to dilate the bronchi and bronchioles, increasing airflow to the lungs.
Chemicals added to solutions to narrow the range the pH can vary.
Cannabinoids encompass several strucural classes of compounds that are found in Cannabis, some of which are psychoactive.
Chemicals that introduce carbon Monoxide into substrates.
Yellow, orange and red organic pigments that give the characteristic colors to pumpkins, carrots, corn, salmon, and other organisms.
Substances that increase the rate of a chemical reaction without itself undergoing any permanent chemical change.
Monoamine neurotransmitters with a catechol and a side-chain amine.
Inorganic entities with a net positive charge.
Chemicals used to promote chelation, a type of bonding of ions and particles to metal ions.
Raw materials that are used to produce goods, energy or chemical intermediates for products.
Chemicals that arise within the sequence of stepwise chemical reactions.
Chemicals whose toxic properties are meant to kill, injure or incapacitate humans.
Compounds that are chlorine-containing and act as disinfecting agents or bleaching agents.
Chemicals that prevent the breakdown of the neurotransmitter acetylcholine or butyrylcholine.
Chemicals that are used to remove suspended solids from liquids.
Chemicals used to remove dirt, dust, stains or foul odors from surfaces or textiles.
Chemicals that improve the quality of a given material, often used in skincare products.
Chemicals that are used as electrical conductors.
Unwanted chemicals that get into consumer products and goods.
Substances used as medications for preventing unintended pregnancies.
A chemical that decreases the corrosion rate of a material.
Substances that are subject to corrosion.
Hormonal steroids that act as glucocorticoid receptor agonists.
Substances that are used as additives in cosmetic items.
Chemicals that are often found as impurities in cosmetic products.
Chemicals that introduce bonds that link one polymer chain to another.
Chemicals used in the curing process of polymers. That is the toughening or hardening of a polymer material by cross-linking polymer chains.
Toxins produced by cyanobacteria, including some of the most potent natural poisons known.
Chemicals used as medications for alleviating nasal congestion in the upper respiratory tract.
Chemicals used as additives in industrial process liquids that reduce the formation of foam.
Chemicals that are used to drive a dehydration reaction. Unique from desiccants.
Chemicals used to bring mixtures out of emulsion.
Chemicals used to remove odors.
Chemicals used lighten the color of skin by removing pigments.
Substances used as drugs to lower neurotransmission levels, or reduces stimulation in various areas of the brain.
Chemicals that are used to remove limescale deposits on metal surfaces.
Substances that absorb moisture from their surroundings.
Surfactants with cleansing properties used to remove soils from a substrate.
A liquid that is an electrical insulator which can be polarised in an electric field.
Chemicals used to dilute a fluid.
Chemicals used to inactivate or destroy microorganisms on inert surfaces.
Chemicals that are byproducts of a disinfecting process.
Chemicals that are added to a susupension of particles in a liquid to improve the separation of the particles to prevent their settling or clumping.
Substances that are a subclass of Hallucinogens that distort one's perception and produces feelings of dissociation.
Substances that bind to cancer-causing chemicals within a region of DNA, generally used as a biomarker of exposure.
A substance that is used as a reuptake inhibitor of dopamine.
Byproducts of the body breaking down some drug or pharmaceutical.
Chemical feedstock for the manufacturing of dyes.
Chemical intermediates that occur in the production of dyes and pigments.
Colored substances that chemically bond to the substrate it is applied to.
Ethylene bisdithiocarbamates, extensively used as fungicides.
Ions that act as charge carriers in electrically conducting mediums.
Chemicals with preservative and or disinfecting properties used in the embalming process to temorarily prevent decomposition of a body after dead.
A chemical that is used as a moisturizer to treat or prevent dry skin and skin irritation.
Chemicals added to immiscible liquids allowing an emulsion to be formed.
Chemicals with stored potential energy that are used as explosives, fuels and propellants.
Cyclic ethers where the ether forms a three-atom ring.
Sex hormones that are mediated by estrogen receptors.
Chemicals used to remove layers from the surfaces of materials.
Chemicals that are used in solutions for euthenasia.
Substances that contain large amounts of potential energy that can be released through an explosion.
Substances that are used as starting materials in the production of explosives.
Chemicals that are carboxylic acids with aliphatic chains.
A substance that is applied to soil to supply plants with nutrients.
Substances that are significantly longer than they are wide.
Chemicals used in textile manufacturing to convert woven or knitted cloth into a usable material by improving the performance, look or feel of the textiles.
Chemicals that are used to slow down or stop the spread of fire. Often added to textiles, plastics and resins.
Chemicals that make up a class of polyphenolic secondary metabolites found in plants.
Food additives used to alter or enhance the flavor profile.
Compounds that donate fluorine in fluorination reactions.
Substances that facilitate the formation of foam. Generally either a surfactant or a blowing agent.
Chemicals used as medications for antagonizing folic acid.
Chemicals added to food items.
Chemicals that are often found as unwanted contaminants in food items.
Food additives used to preserve the freshness of foods.
Chemicals used to add or enhance aroma profiles.
Chemicals added to fuels.
Chemicals that have stored potential energy that can be used to release thermal energy to be used for work.
Chemicals used in fumigation, a method of pest control by filling a volume with gaseous biocides.
Substances that are used as starting materials in the production of fungicides.
Pesticides that are used to kill parasitic fungi or their spores.
Substances that induce a reversible loss of conciousness.
Haloacetic acids are carboxylic acids in which a halogen atom takes the place of a hydrogen atom in acetic acid.
Psychoactive substances that produce altered states of conciousness characterized by major alterations in thought, mood and perception.
Chemicals in which one or more carbon atoms are linked with one or more halogen atoms.
Pollutants that are known or suspected to cause cancer or other serious health effects, as determined by the USEPA.
Chemicals used in the carburizing process of metals.
Chemicals that act as an intermediary in heat transfer protocols by transporting thermal energy.
Metals with realtively high densities, atomic weights or atomic numbers.
Substances that are used as starting materials in the production of herbicides.
Pesticides that are used to kill or destroy unwanted vegetation.
Signaling molecules in organisms that are used to regulate physiology and behavior.
Hygroscopic chemicals used to keep products moist.
Substances that are used to lower the level of lipids such as cholesterol in the blood.
Chemicals that are used in the liquid mediums by which power is transferred in hydraulic machinery.
Substances that are the end product for some industrial use. For example, cement.
Chemicals that lack carbon-hydrogen bonds.
Chemicals that cause reproductive sterility in insects.
Chemicals that are applied to surfaces to repel insects.
Chemicals that are added to insecticides.
Substances that are used as starting materials in the production of insecticides.
Pesticides that are used to kill or control insects.
Chemicals that donate ions during ion exchange reactions.
Chemicals with the isocyanate functional group.
Substituted derivatives of Isoflavone, many of which act as phytoestrogens.
Chemicals that are commonly found in laboratories for use as reagents, cleaning agents, or other purposes.
Chemicals used as medications to loosen stool and increase bowel movements.
Pesticides whose use has been discontinued.
Substances that induce a reversible loss of sensation in a limited region of the body.
Chemicals used as lubricants or as additives in lubricants.
Chemicals used to react with another chemical species that may interfere with the desired reaction.
Chemicals used to sterilize medical equipment.
An element that has an aggregate of properties from metals and nonmetals.
A material that is generally lustrous, and acts as a good electric and thermal conductor.
Chemicals that donate a methyl group during methylation.
Fragments of any type of plastic less than 5mm in length.
Pesticides used to kill or control molluscs.
Molecules that can react with other monomers to form larger polymer chains.
Toxic chemicals produced by fungi.
Fragments of any type of plastic less than 1mcm in length.
Mixtures of cyclopentyl and cyclohexyl carboxylic acids.
Any psychoactive compound with numbing or paralyzing properties. Typically associated with opioids.
Pesticides used to kill parasitic nematodes.
Substances that are chemically similar to nicotine, which are used as insecticides.
Chemicals that disrupt the mechanisms by which nerves communicate messages.
Signaling molecules that are released by neurons to affect another cell across a synapse.
Materials that are used to reflect neutrons.
Chemicals that on the list of HighResNPS mass spectral database for HR-MS screening of New Psychoactive Substances that do not fall into a more refined category.
Organic compounds that feature a nitroso group bonded to a deprotonated amine.
Analogues of a nucleobase.
Nitrogen containing compounds that form necleosides, which make up nucleotides.
Substances consumed by an organism to survive, grow and reproduce.
Substances that act on opioid receptors.
Chemicals that absorb light in the UV and violet range and re-emit light in the blue range through fluorescence.
A chemical that accepts an electron from a reducing agent in a redox reaction.
Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons.
Chemicals that are used as additives in paints.
Organic compounds that are a series of parahydroxybenzoates or esters of parahydroxybenzoic acid, which are commonly used as Preservatives and Stabilizing Agents in PPCPs.
Polybrominated biphenyls.
Polybrominated dibenzo-p-dioxins.
Polybrominated diphenyl ethers.
Polychlorinated biphenyls.
Polychlorinated dibenzodioxins.
Polychlorinated dibenzofurans.
Polychlorinated naphthalene.
Chemicals added to products (food, pharmaceuticals, paint, etc…) to prevent decomposition or other undesirable chemical changes.
Chemicals that are often found as impurities in personal care products.
Chemicals that are used as additives in pesticides.
Chemical Intermediates that arise during the synthesis of pesticides.
Substances that are used as starting materials in the production of pesticides.
Substances that are used to kill and control pests.
Materials that are derived from crude oil.
Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances.
Polyfluorinated compounds.
Chemicals used to control the pH of a solution.
Chemicals that are used as additives in pharmaceuticals.
Unwanted chemicals that get into pharmaceuticals.
Chemical intermediates that arise during the synthesis of pharmaceuticals.
Chemicals used as starting materials for the synthesis of pharmaceuticals.
Chemicals used as medicinal drugs.
Organic compounds consisting of one or more hydroxyl groups bonded directly to an aromatic hydrocarbon group.
Preservatives and Stabilizing Agents that prevent chemical degradation due to light exposure.
Materials that convert light into electricity.
Esters of phthalic acid, primarily used as plasticizers.
Naturally occuring steroids that are found in plants.
Colored substances that are insoluble in water.
Pesticides that are used to kill and control fish.
Chemicals substances that control the growth and development within plants. Often used to increase branching of a plant, remove excess fruit, or altering fruit maturity.
An intermediate or end product of plant metabolism.
Chemicals that are added to plastics.
Chemicals that are added to a material to make it softer and more flexible or to increase its plasticity.
Chemicals that are used as plastics.
Chemicals that absorb liquid and transforms it into a powder.
Chemicals added to monomers to prevent auto-polymerisation.
Substances made from macromolecules composed of many repeating subunits.
Organic compounds that have multiple phenol groups.
Organic compounds that are resistant to degradation through chemical, biological and photolytic processes.
Chemicals that are used in pharmaceuticals and personal care products.
Chemicals added to products (food, pharmaceuticals, paint, etc…) to prevent decomposition or other undesirable chemical changes.
Mass that is expelled or expanded in such a way to accelerate a vehicle or projectile. Often times used interchangeably with the term 'fuel'.
Chemicals used to modify a functional group on a molecule to obtain chemoselectivity in a subsqequent chemical reaction.
Chemicals that act as hallucinogenic drugs. Often used recreationally.
Quarternary ammonium cations
Chemicals used as broad-spectrum antibiotics.
Substances that emit radioactive radiation.
Chemicals that are consumed recreationally for their psychoactive properties.
A chemical that donates an electron to an oxidizing agent in a redox reaction.
Chemicals that are used in the refrigeration cycle of air conditioning systems and heat pumps.
Chemicals that are used in labs for research -- not intended for consumption by humans or other animals.
Pesticides used to kill and control rodent pests.
Chemicals that are added to rubber.
A subclass of terpenes.
Chemicals that remove impurities found in textiles.
Chemicals used in sealants, which are substances that block the passage of fluids through openings.
Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors.
Drugs used to relieve anxiety and or to initiate, sustain or prolong sleep.
Chemicals that are used as additives in soil.
Substances that dissolve some solute.
Steroids that act as hormones.
Organic compounds with four fused rings arranged in a specific molecular configuration.
Chemicals that are used to increase central nervous system activity.
Chemicals that are sweet-tasting, soluble carbohydrates.
Chemicals with a sulfonamide functional group.
Chemicals that decrease the surface tension or interfacial tension between two fluids, or a liquid and a solid.
Chemicals added to food items to increase their sweetness.
Substances that absorb large amounts of water, increasing their volume significantly.
Lab-made substances that are chemically similar to natural cannabinoids.
A class of naturally occuring organic chemicals that are found in all classes of living organisms.
Chemicals that are used to increase the viscosity of a liquid.
Trihalomethanes.
Naturally occuring organic poisons produced by living cells or organisms.
Esters derived from glycerol and three fatty acids.
Chemicals that are used to absorb UV light.
Chemical substances of unknown or variable composition.
Chemicals that are added to veterinary drugs.
Metabolites of veterinary drugs.
Chemicals used for medicinal purposes in the context of veterinary care.
Chemicals that are used to alter the viscosity of a liquid.
Organic compounds that are essential for normal growth and are required to be consumed through dietary sources because they cannot be synthesized by the body.
Volatile organic compounds.
Chemicals that are used to accelerate the curing process of rubber.
Byproducts of water treatment processes.
Chemicals used in the water treatment process for clean drinking water.
Chemicals added to an object to increase its water-resistance.
Chemicals used to increase a liquid's ability to maintain contact with a solid surface.
